EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:



This document contains the updated risk management plan for the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP RMP) for the Mountain House Water Treatment Plant (MHWTP) located at 18045 Kelso Rod, Mountain House, CA, 95391.



The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning requirements as set forth in the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Article 3. The CalARP RMP is for the aqueous ammonia that is stored at the plant for use in drinking water treatment.



1. DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The sole purpose of the MHWTP is to treat reservoir water for use in drinking water (NAICS code 22131 Water Utilities).



MHWTP is a water treatment plant that uses ammonia to produce chloramines, which act as a residual disinfectant to protect against pathogens in drinking water. 



The MHWTP has a maximum inventory of 3,200 liquid gallons of aqueous ammonia (4,670 lbs NH3).



A metal fence and a security system protect the site, and all building entries are equipped with intruder alarms to alert use of unauthorized access.



2. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to limit the risk of release the operations staff must be properly trained. The operators will become familiar with the following information:

?    Material Safety Data Sheets

?    Maximum intended inventory

?    Safe upper and lower parameters

?    Equipment specifications

?    Codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the process



3. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have not been any accidents on site or any accidental releases of regulated substances.



4. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 



In the event of a spill or release the following steps will take place.

1)Call the local emergency response agency: 911

2)Call the fire department: (209) 831-6700.

3)Call Cal OES: (800) 852-7550

4)Call the San Joaquin Office of Emergency Services:

(209) 953-6200.



5. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following changes are planned in response to the hazards identified during the hazard review. 

1)Provide windsock in visible location.

2)Set-up emergency response team.

3)Post warning sign on the outside of the chemical building.

3)Add label to aqueous ammonia chemical piping at the Finished Water Storage Effluent injection point.

4)Remove hose tripping hazard near the emergency eyewash station within the chemical building.



Mike Buckley will be responsible for implementing these changes by February 14, 2014.
